articles.title: NI to become first in the UK to introduce graduated driving licences
articles.summary: The new rules will be introduced in October and are described as the most significant reform of driver licensing for 70 years.
articles.content:
NI to become first in the UK to introduce graduated driving licences

5 hours ago Share Save Julie McCullough BBC News NI Share Save

Getty Images The new rules are aimed at 17 to 23-year-olds and will change how people learn to drive

Northern Ireland will become the first area of the UK to bring in graduated driver licensing for learner drivers in a bid to reduce the amount of fatal road crashes involving young people, it has been announced. The reforms, described as the most significant changes to licencing in 70 years, will see Northern Ireland adopt a version of laws in place in countries including Australia, the US and the Republic of Ireland. The rules, due to be introduced in October, are aimed at 17 to 23-year-olds and will change how people learn to drive. They include a six-month wait for learner drivers before taking a practical test, as well as restrictions on night-time driving and passenger numbers.

Infrastructure Minister Liz Kimmins said the changes were "aimed at young drivers who are sadly most likely to be killed or seriously injured on our roads". A senior Police Service of Northern Ireland (PSNI) officer, Ch Supt Sam Donaldson, said the scheme would save lives on the roads. Some young people who spoke to BBC News NI gave a mixed reaction to the reforms, with one saying they were "not looking forward to the changes".

James,15, says he is a bit "shocked" that he will have to wait six months before taking his driving test

Why is graduated driver licensing coming into NI?

The Department for Infrastructure said graduated driving licences were aimed at revising training and testing for new drivers and motorcyclists. The minister said that in 2024, there were 164 people killed or seriously injured in Northern Ireland's roads from crashes caused by a driver aged between 17 and 23. "This age group of drivers account for 24% of fatal or serious collisions despite holding just 8% of licences," she added. Pat Delaney, director of operations in the Driver and Vehicle Agency Northern Ireland (DVANI) said the new measures would affect anyone who gets a provisional driving licence from 1 October. He said the overall aim of these changes was to "improve road safety" for young people.

What are in NI's graduate driving license rules?

The major rule changes are: New drivers will not be permitted to take their driving test for at least six months after being granted a provisional licence

They must also complete 14 modules in a programme of training, which has to be signed off by an approved driving instructor or a supervising driver that could be a parent or guardian

An increase in the restriction period from 12 months to 24 months requiring new drivers to display an 'R' plate style mark on their vehicles after passing their test - a different colour of 'R' plate will signify a driver in their initial six-month period

For the first six months after passing their test, new drivers up to the age of 24 are only permitted to have one passenger aged between 14 and 20 in their car between the hours of 23:00 and 06:00

That restriction would not include immediate family members and does not apply if someone aged 21 or over, who has held a drivers licence for at least three years, is sitting in the front seat

Learner drivers will be allowed to drive on the motorway if accompanied by an approved instructor and will be allowed to drive on the motorway up to the posted speed limit, after passing their test The current speed limit of 45mph for restricted drivers will also be removed. Drivers who do not follow the restrictions could receive three penalty points or a fine of up to £1,000. PSNI Ch Supt Donaldson welcomed the scheme, and said he wished it was introduced immediately. "Young people who are 17, 18 and new drivers regardless of what age, they don't recognise the risk the way perhaps some of us here a little bit older do," he said. "So I absolutely welcome this graduated response, some restrictions in terms of who they can carry, times of day they can travel and things like that because we've got to bring our new drivers on a slower journey to allow them to learn how to drive on the roads. "That's the way it's done in Scandinavia and they have far safer roads than we have, so we've got to learn from them and we've got to bring this in." The Department for Infrastructure said it would shortly launch a public information campaign about graduated driver licensing, and officials would liaise with approved instructors, the PSNI and a range of others ahead of the new rules being introduced.

What have young people said about the changes?

15-year-old Oliver understands why they are making the changes

At St Mark's High School in Warrenpoint, County Down, present and past pupils from the GCSE Motor Vehicle & Road User Studies class give their reaction to the changes. Oliver, 15, said: "It would be a bit of an annoyance to not be able to drive right way" but he does think it makes sense. "There are people who get their licence too early and aren't experienced enough on the road to be going out and driving themselves."

Cormac, 17, would not have wanted to wait six months before getting his test

Cormac - who passed his driving test in less than six months after his 17th birthday - said he would have understood if they required a "minimum lessons amount". But he does welcome the removal of the 45mph speed limit. "When you're on a dual carriageway and having to go 45mph it does feel more dangerous than safe," he said.

Amy, 18, said restricting passenger numbers at night could end up costing more money

Amy, 18, has not got her drivers licence yet, but said she did not like the idea of restricting the passengers she is allowed to take at night time. "Instead of taking one car load you'd maybe have to take three," she said, adding she accepts it is probably for the "greater good". "You wouldn't be getting distracted as much if your friends were sitting beside you trying to show you something."

17-year-old Matthew got his driving test within three months of his birthday

Matthew, 17, said it would prevent him from being able to give someone a lift home late at night but thinks it would be safer. "The majority of accidents do happen at those times. It is safer for everyone."

What's the view from driving instructors?

Driving instructor Peter Carmichael welcomes the changes but wants to see more details
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Northern Ireland introducing graduated driving licences to reduce fatal road crashes among young drivers, a significant policy reform with broad public safety impact. The changes are the most significant in 70 years and aim to save lives by improving driver training and imposing sensible restrictions. The article provides detailed context on the new rules, their rationale, and reactions from officials and young people, demonstrating substance and meaningful societal benefit.
articles.personality_title: Northern Ireland to introduce new graduated driving licences for young drivers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Northern Ireland is changing how young people learn to drive to make roads safer. Young drivers aged 17 to 23 are involved in many serious accidents, even though they make up a small part of all drivers.

**What happened** – Starting in October, Northern Ireland will be the first part of the UK to use graduated driving licences. This means new drivers must wait six months before taking their driving test and complete special training. After passing, they will have restrictions like fewer passengers at night and special 'R' plates on their cars to show they are new drivers.

**Impact** – These new rules are the biggest change to driver licensing in 70 years in Northern Ireland. They aim to reduce crashes by helping young drivers gain experience safely. For example, limiting passengers at night reduces distractions, and the longer learning period helps drivers become better prepared.

**What's next step** – The government will start a campaign to explain the new rules to young people, driving instructors, and the police. Officials will work with these groups to make sure everyone understands and follows the new system.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Northern Ireland is leading the UK with new driving rules that help young drivers learn safely and reduce accidents on the road.

**Contexto** – Irlanda del Norte está cambiando la forma en que los jóvenes aprenden a conducir para hacer las carreteras más seguras. Los conductores de 17 a 23 años están involucrados en muchos accidentes graves, aunque representan una pequeña parte de todos los conductores.

articles.title: Caribbean cannabis growers eye budding domestic sales and exports
articles.summary: Producers in Jamaica and Antigua hope that increasing liberalisation will lead to higher revenues.
articles.content:
Caribbean cannabis growers eye budding domestic sales and exports

22 hours ago Share Save Gemma Handy Business reporter, St John’s, Antigua Share Save

Gemma Handy Antiguan cannabis grower Michaelus Tracey says that a lot of effort is put into developing new strains

Rub the leaf and inhale the fragrance, Michaelus Tracey is saying. The musky scent of this cannabis plant is distinctly different from the citrusy aroma of another that he is also holding. To the untrained eye, the neat rows of flowering cannabis crops in front of us are indistinguishable from each other. Yet master cultivator Tracey can identify the separate varieties by their smell and the shape of their leaves. Nine strains are being grown here at Pineapple Road, a farm deep in the countryside on the Caribbean island of Antigua. The warm temperatures, abundant sunshine, and high humidity make this prime territory for growing the plants. Intense trials were conducted to produce the various strains, Tracey explains. "We wanted different flavour profiles as well as different effects, but all with a medicinal value - something to help you relax, something to give you more energy, more pain relief, less anxiety."

Gemma Handy Cannibis plants thrive in Antigua's warm, sunny conditions

Last year marked a decade since Jamaica decriminalised the recreational use of cannabis and legalised its production and sale for medical reasons. Several other Caribbean nations, including the twin island country Antigua and Barbuda in 2018, have since followed suit. Smoking cannabis is emblematic of Caribbean culture, to the extent it has become a cliché. But while the region's affection for the plant is well documented, its status as a leader in the field is less so. Today the region is home to a plethora of legally registered cannabis farms and medicinal dispensaries, where both locals and tourists can purchase the drug if they have a valid medical authorisation card. Yet Prof Rose-Marie Belle Antoine, an expert on the cannabis industry in the Caribbean, believes there needs to be further liberalisation. "Decriminalisation isn't good enough," says Antoine, a former chair of the Caribbean Community's Regional Commission on Marijuana. "We should just make it legal but regulated." Antoine is campus principal at the University of the West Indies in Trinidad, where researchers are due to start studying various potential benefits of cannabis. Areas tipped for study range from alleviating the side effects of cancer treatment, to how the plant can boost agriculture by improving soil health. The research will take place in Antigua, where legislation is more progressive. The work offers "a lot of potential", she says, but adds that legalisation would make life easier. "The Caribbean is a leader in cannabis, in terms of strains and knowledge, and it has a long tradition of this. But legalities, the 'war on drugs' and all that nonsense, stifled not just the industry, but research and development," says Antoine.

Some in the region hope that US President Donald Trump's executive order in December to reclassify cannabis as a lower-level drug will benefit the Caribbean. "It's a significant milestone," says Alexandra Chong, chief executive of Jamaica-based business Jacana, which sells a range of products derived from cannabis, from extract oil drops to skin cream. "So much US public policy gets filtered down to the Caribbean," she says. "Because cannabis was classified as a schedule one drug alongside heroin in the US, regulatory bodies across the Caribbean have not been as bullish with [reducing] regulation." Chong adds that the US reducing cannabis to the lower schedule three level, which also includes combined paracetamol-codeine tablets, was "far more appropriate". The White House lowering the classification of cannabis may mean that in the future Caribbean nations can export the drug to the US for recreational use. However, the importation of such cannabis into the US is currently still illegal under federal law. This is despite 24 US states having now legalised the use of the drug recreationally. Producers in both Jamaica and Antigua are keen to start legally exporting the drug. Jamaica's Cannabis Licensing Authority says it "has put in place interim administrative procedures to facilitate the export of ganja by licensees that hold a valid import permit from the country that the product will be exported to". Meanwhile, Antigua and Barbuda's Medicinal Cannabis Authority is working hard to develop a cannabis export industry. "We already have the legal framework in place, a prime geographical location and an international airport," the body's chief executive Regis Burton tells the BBC. He says it's "highly likely" that Antigua will eventually be able to export its products, not least for the novelty value. "Very few people can say they've tried Antiguan cannabis," he adds.

Jacana Alexandra Chong hopes that Trump's move will lead to more liberalisation in the Caribbean

Domestically, high overheads in both Jamaica and Antigua and Barbuda – and rules that limit the sale of cannabis to people with medical approval - are said to be leaving most of the market to illegal producers. Jacana estimates that more than 800,000 people a year in Jamaica use cannabis, of whom half are tourists. But that 90% of the 87 tonnes of the drug consumed per annum comes through illicit channels. Chong adds that "over-regulation has strangled the industry. Over time it's got easier, but it's by no means perfect". She says that due to these problems, she estimates that of the 160-plus licences of various categories granted by Jamaica's Cannabis Licensing Authority between 2017 and 2024, "very few" are still in operation. In Antigua, Robert Hill, a consultant to the industry, says: "It's still more profitable to import cannabis illegally. Unlike dealers, private companies have staff and bills to pay." Currently the island has just six cannabis farms, four dispensaries and a cannabis lounge, where people can smoke on the premises. At the same time, Antiguan authorities intercepted 45kg of illegally imported cannabis in just 24 hours back in September. Meanwhile, Antigua has been innovative in its approach to domestic illegal growers. Instead of prosecutions, violators were invited to take part in a free six-week course to teach them how to enter the market legally. "Twenty-two have already graduated, with two soon to transition to a medicinal business," Burton tells the BBC. "The industry won't be successful if the illicit market does as it pleases."

The continuing liberalisation of cannabis across the Caribbean is also said to be having a positive impact on social justice for one community in particular. In 2018, Antigua's Prime Minister Gaston Browne issued a formal apology to the country's Rastafarians, for decades of historic persecution, stigma and abuse over their cannabis use. Six years later, the government granted Rastafarians official sacramental authorisation to grow the plants. And last summer, it announced plans to expunge the criminal records of people previously prosecuted for possession of small amounts of marijuana.

Gemma Handy Rastafarian High Priest Selah, left, says that efforts to allow the legal use of cannabis were hard fought
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the progressive liberalisation and legalisation of cannabis in Caribbean countries like Jamaica and Antigua, which has broad positive impacts including economic opportunities, social justice advancements such as expunging criminal records and official apologies to persecuted communities, and potential medical research benefits. This represents a meaningful societal shift with tangible benefits for many people in the region, addressing both economic and human rights issues.
articles.personality_title: Caribbean countries expand legal cannabis use, boosting economy and social justice
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Caribbean nations like Jamaica and Antigua have a long history with cannabis, traditionally used for cultural and medicinal purposes. In recent years, these countries have begun to change their laws to allow legal growing, selling, and using of cannabis, especially for medical reasons.

**What happened** – Jamaica decriminalised cannabis ten years ago, and Antigua followed in 2018. Today, both countries have legal cannabis farms and shops where people with medical approval can buy cannabis. Growers like Michaelus Tracey in Antigua develop different cannabis strains with unique smells and effects, aiming to help with pain, relaxation, and energy. The Caribbean is working on expanding this legal market, including hopes to export cannabis to other countries like the US, which recently lowered cannabis’s drug classification.

**Impact** – This legal shift is important because it creates new business opportunities and jobs in farming and selling cannabis. It also helps fix past social problems; for example, Antigua’s government apologized to Rastafarians for punishing them over cannabis use and is clearing criminal records for small cannabis offenses. The region’s warm climate makes it ideal for growing many types of cannabis, which could also lead to new medical research on its benefits.

**What's next step** – Researchers at the University of the West Indies will study how cannabis can help with health issues like cancer side effects and improve farming. Governments plan to make cannabis laws even more open and easier to follow, which could reduce illegal sales and allow legal exports. Antigua is training illegal growers to join the legal market, helping the industry grow safely.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Caribbean countries are expanding legal cannabis use and sales, creating new economic chances and addressing past social injustices.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les pays des Caraïbes développent l'usage légal du cannabis, stimulant l'économie et la justice sociale
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Des pays caribéens comme la Jamaïque et Antigua ont une longue histoire avec le cannabis, utilisé traditionnellement pour des raisons culturelles et médicinales. Ces dernières années, ces pays ont commencé à modifier leurs lois pour permettre la culture, la vente et l'usage légaux du cannabis, surtout à des fins médicales.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – La Jamaïque a dépénalisé le cannabis il y a dix ans, suivie par Antigua en 2018. Aujourd'hui, ces deux pays ont des fermes et des boutiques légales où les personnes avec une autorisation médicale peuvent acheter du cannabis. Des cultivateurs comme Michaelus Tracey à Antigua développent différentes variétés de cannabis avec des odeurs et effets uniques, visant à aider pour la douleur, la relaxation et l'énergie. La région des Caraïbes travaille à étendre ce marché légal, avec l'espoir d'exporter vers des pays comme les États-Unis, qui ont récemment abaissé la classification du cannabis.

**Impact** – Ce changement légal est important car il crée de nouvelles opportunités d'affaires et d'emplois dans la culture et la vente du cannabis. Il aide aussi à réparer des problèmes sociaux passés ; par exemple, le gouvernement d'Antigua a présenté des excuses aux rastafariens pour les avoir punis à cause du cannabis et efface les casiers judiciaires pour les petites infractions liées au cannabis. Le climat chaud de la région est idéal pour cultiver de nombreuses variétés, ce qui pourrait aussi ouvrir la voie à de nouvelles recherches médicales.

**Prochaine étape** – Des chercheurs de l'Université des Indes occidentales étudieront comment le cannabis peut aider pour des problèmes de santé comme les effets secondaires du cancer et améliorer l'agriculture. Les gouvernements prévoient de rendre les lois sur le cannabis encore plus ouvertes et faciles à suivre, ce qui pourrait réduire les ventes illégales et permettre des exportations légales. Antigua forme les cultivateurs illégaux pour qu'ils rejoignent le marché légal, aidant ainsi à faire grandir l'industrie de façon sûre.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les pays des Caraïbes étendent l'usage et la vente légaux du cannabis, créant de nouvelles chances économiques et réparant des injustices sociales passées.
articles.personality_title_es: Países caribeños amplían el uso legal del cannabis, impulsando economía y justicia social
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Países del Caribe como Jamaica y Antigua tienen una larga historia con el cannabis, usado tradicionalmente por razones culturales y medicinales. En los últimos años, estos países han comenzado a cambiar sus leyes para permitir el cultivo, la venta y el uso legal del cannabis, especialmente para fines médicos.

**Qué pasó** – Jamaica despenalizó el cannabis hace diez años, y Antigua lo hizo en 2018. Hoy, ambos países cuentan con granjas y tiendas legales donde las personas con aprobación médica pueden comprar cannabis. Cultivadores como Michaelus Tracey en Antigua desarrollan diferentes variedades de cannabis con olores y efectos únicos, buscando ayudar con el dolor, la relajación y la energía. También ayuda a corregir problemas sociales pasados; por ejemplo, el gobierno de Antigua pidió disculpas a los rastafaris por castigarlos por el uso de cannabis y está borrando antecedentes penales por pequeñas infracciones relacionadas con la marihuana. El clima cálido de la región es ideal para cultivar muchos tipos de cannabis, lo que también podría llevar a nuevas investigaciones médicas.

**Próximo paso** – Investigadores de la Universidad de las Indias Occidentales estudiarán cómo el cannabis puede ayudar con problemas de salud como los efectos secundarios del cáncer y mejorar la agricultura. Antigua está formando a cultivadores ilegales para que ingresen al mercado legal, ayudando a que la industria crezca de forma segura.

articles.title: ICC’s Work Vital for Justice in Darfur
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Displaced people from Darfur, who are now sheltering  in El-Afadh camp, Al Dabbah, Sudan, November 13, 2025.
                    © 2025 Marwan Ali/AP Photo 
          
    


  
On January 19, International Criminal Court (ICC) Deputy Prosecutor Nazhat Shameem Khan briefed the United Nations Security Council on her office’s ongoing investigation in Darfur, Sudan.Deputy Prosecutor Khan had to attend the briefing remotely after not being granted a visa to brief the Council in person in New York City. Khan reported to the Council her office’s findings of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in El Fasher by the RSF during its siege and control of the city, warning that RSF is replicating a “pattern of atrocities” in different parts of Darfur. Khan also called onstates to provide “additional assistance and investment of resources” to support the court’s investigative work in Darfur.The office of the prosecutor has been investigating serious crimes in Darfur since 2005, following a referral by the Security Council. In 2025, 20 years after the referral, the ICC convicted Ali Kosheib, a former leader of the “Janjaweed,” a militia created by the government of former Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir, on numerous counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Darfur in 2003-2004. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison.This long-awaited conviction provided the first opportunity for victims in Darfur to see a measure of justice before the ICC. With the current impunity-fueled conflict in Sudan, the ICC has a vital role in bringing further justice. The US sanctions, however, risk undermining the court’s ability to carry out its global mandate.After Khan’s briefing, ICC members on the Security Council jointly noted with regret Khan’s inability to brief them in person and reiterated their commitment to safeguard the principles enshrined in the court’s founding treaty.Security Council and ICC members should stand by their words and redouble efforts to support and protect the court, including by taking concrete steps to ensure continuation of the court’s critical work, providing adequate resources, and urging the Trump administration to revoke its ICC-related sanctions regime.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Displaced people from Darfur, who are now sheltering in El-Afadh camp, Al Dabbah, Sudan, November 13, 2025. © 2025 Marwan Ali/AP Photo

On January 19, International Criminal Court (ICC) Deputy Prosecutor Nazhat Shameem Khan briefed the United Nations Security Council on her office’s ongoing investigation in Darfur, Sudan.

Deputy Prosecutor Khan had to attend the briefing remotely after not being granted a visa to brief the Council in person in New York City. That decision came in the wake of the Trump administration’s sanctions imposed against a number of ICC officials, including Khan in 2025.

The briefing took place as the situation in Darfur continues to deteriorate. In October 2025, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) carried out mass killings and other grave abuses in North Darfur’s capital, El Fasher. Khan reported to the Council her office’s findings of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in El Fasher by the RSF during its siege and control of the city, warning that RSF is replicating a “pattern of atrocities” in different parts of Darfur. Khan also called onstates to provide “additional assistance and investment of resources” to support the court’s investigative work in Darfur.

The office of the prosecutor has been investigating serious crimes in Darfur since 2005, following a referral by the Security Council. In 2025, 20 years after the referral, the ICC convicted Ali Kosheib, a former leader of the “Janjaweed,” a militia created by the government of former Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir, on numerous counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Darfur in 2003-2004. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison.

This long-awaited conviction provided the first opportunity for victims in Darfur to see a measure of justice before the ICC. With the current impunity-fueled conflict in Sudan, the ICC has a vital role in bringing further justice. The US sanctions, however, risk undermining the court’s ability to carry out its global mandate.

After Khan’s briefing, ICC members on the Security Council jointly noted with regret Khan’s inability to brief them in person and reiterated their commitment to safeguard the principles enshrined in the court’s founding treaty.

Security Council and ICC members should stand by their words and redouble efforts to support and protect the court, including by taking concrete steps to ensure continuation of the court’s critical work, providing adequate resources, and urging the Trump administration to revoke its ICC-related sanctions regime.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant milestone in international justice with the ICC's conviction of a war criminal responsible for atrocities in Darfur, providing victims with a measure of justice after two decades. It underscores the ICC's ongoing role in investigating and addressing war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur, which has broad humanitarian significance. Despite challenges such as US sanctions, the story reflects meaningful progress in upholding human rights and international law.
articles.personality_title: ICC marks progress in Darfur justice with historic war crimes conviction
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Darfur region of Sudan has suffered from violent conflict and serious crimes for many years. Since 2005, the International Criminal Court (ICC) has been investigating war crimes and crimes against humanity there, following a request from the United Nations Security Council.

**What happened** – On January 19, 2026, ICC Deputy Prosecutor Nazhat Shameem Khan updated the UN Security Council about recent findings in Darfur. She spoke remotely because she was denied a visa to travel to New York, due to US sanctions against some ICC officials. Khan reported that in October 2025, a militia called the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) committed mass killings and other abuses in El Fasher, the capital of North Darfur. She warned that similar attacks are continuing in other parts of Darfur. She also asked countries to provide more support and resources to help the ICC continue its investigations.

**Impact** – A major milestone was reached in 2025 when the ICC convicted Ali Kosheib, a former militia leader known as Janjaweed, for war crimes committed in 2003-2004. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison. This was the first time victims in Darfur saw justice through the ICC after two decades. The ICC’s ongoing work is crucial because violence and abuses still happen in the region. However, US sanctions could make it harder for the ICC to do its work worldwide.

**What's next step** – The Security Council and ICC members expressed regret that Khan could not speak in person and promised to protect the ICC’s mission. They need to increase support, provide enough resources, and encourage the US to lift sanctions on ICC officials. This will help the court keep investigating and bringing justice to victims in Darfur and other conflict zones.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The ICC’s conviction of a Darfur war criminal marks important progress in justice, but continued support is needed to address ongoing crimes and protect the court’s work worldwide.

articles.personality_title_es: La CPI avanza en la justicia de Darfur con una condena histórica por crímenes de guerra

Khan informó que en octubre de 2025, una milicia llamada Fuerzas de Apoyo Rápido (RSF) cometió asesinatos masivos y otros abusos en El Fasher, la capital del norte de Darfur. Esto ayudará a la Corte a seguir investigando y llevando justicia a las víctimas en Darfur y en otras zonas de conflicto.

articles.title: Photiou: The Western Balkans remain of strategic importance for the EU, we recognize North Macedonia’s commitment to aligning with European standards
articles.summary: The Cypriot presidency is paying attention to regular and open dialogue with the Western Balkans, and North Macedonia remains part of the Union’s enlargement process. Cyprus recognizes North Macedonia’s commitment to advancing reforms and aligning with European standards and encourages the country’s constant and continuous efforts in that direction, said Fotiou.
articles.content:
The Cypriot presidency is paying attention to regular and open dialogue with the Western Balkans, and North Macedonia remains part of the Union’s enlargement process. Cyprus recognizes North Macedonia’s commitment to advancing reforms and aligning with European standards and encourages the country’s constant and continuous efforts in that direction, said Fotiou.

Skopje – The Cypriot ambassador to North Macedonia, Andreas Fotiou, today, before the joint session of the National Council for Euro-Integration and the Parliamentary Committee on European Affairs, presented the priorities of Cyprus as the current holder of the EU presidency for the next six months, emphasizing that Cyprus will remain committed to regular and open dialogue with the Western Balkans, and that North Macedonia remains part of the EU enlargement process.

Fotiou pointed out that the Cypriot presidency, whose motto is “An autonomous Union open to the world”, means that the European Union must be autonomous because a more autonomous Union will demonstrate the necessary internal strength to cooperate with external partners whenever possible, while at the same time acting independently when necessary, respecting international law and order.

The Cypriot ambassador stressed that the Western Balkans remains a region of strategic importance for the EU, and the Union’s engagement with North Macedonia will continue with a credible, merit-based policy.

– The Cypriot presidency pays attention to regular and open dialogue with the Western Balkans, and North Macedonia remains part of the Union’s enlargement process. Cyprus recognizes North Macedonia’s commitment to advancing reforms and aligning with European standards and encourages the country’s constant and continuous efforts in that direction – said Fotiou.

The ambassador presented the five pillars of the Cypriot presidency of the Union, according to which, he pointed out, Cyprus will focus on autonomy through security and defense, autonomy through competitiveness, openness to the world, shared values, and negotiations on the budget for the next EU financial framework.

The newly appointed Minister for European Affairs Bekim Sali, in his address at the session, pointed out that the country’s European integration is not an administrative process, nor a technical agenda, but a civilizational determination that enjoys social support.

– For us, European integration is a clear state orientation that unites the government and the opposition, the institutions and the citizens. In a time of serious geopolitical turmoil, the enlargement policy is not an option but a necessity; it is also an investment in a stable and autonomous EU. In this picture, North Macedonia is part of the solution – said Sali.

He emphasized that the country continuously shows that it is a credible and responsible partner with the EU.

According to him, the accession process is not easy, which is why the country does not treat the implementation of reforms as an externally imposed obligation, but as an internal issue. This, Sali says, is our conscious political choice to strengthen the state and institutional capacities.

– For us, EU enlargement is an inseparable part of this vision. Europe cannot be complete if the Western Balkans remains on the margins; North Macedonia is ready to close that European political gap and become part of those agreements. That is why today we are sending a clear message – North Macedonia is ready, and this is a moment of political maturity both for North Macedonia and for the EU, a moment that neither we nor the EU must miss – emphasized Sali. (26 January 2026)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on North Macedonia's ongoing commitment to reforms and alignment with European standards as part of the EU enlargement process, which represents a meaningful political and social progress with broad implications for regional stability, governance, and integration. The focus on dialogue, reform, and inclusion in the EU reflects a significant positive development for the Western Balkans and the EU, promoting democratic values and cooperation.
articles.personality_title: Cyprus supports North Macedonia’s progress in joining the EU
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – North Macedonia is working to join the European Union (EU), a group of 27 countries in Europe. This process requires the country to make many changes to meet EU rules and standards. Cyprus currently leads the EU and is helping guide this process.

**What happened** – Cyprus, through its ambassador Andreas Fotiou, said it will keep talking openly and regularly with the Western Balkans, including North Macedonia. Cyprus recognizes North Macedonia’s ongoing efforts to improve its laws and systems to match those of the EU. This was shared during a meeting with North Macedonia’s officials on January 26, 2026.

**Impact** – This support is important because it shows that the EU values North Macedonia’s work and wants the country to become a member. Joining the EU means North Macedonia can benefit from closer cooperation with other European countries, stronger democratic institutions, and more stability in the region. It also shows that the EU is focused on fairness, rewarding countries based on their efforts.

**What's next step** – North Macedonia will continue working on reforms to meet EU requirements. The EU, led by Cyprus for the next six months, will keep encouraging open dialogue and support. Both sides hope to move forward in the enlargement process, bringing North Macedonia closer to EU membership.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Cyprus, leading the EU, praises North Macedonia’s steady reforms and promises to support its journey toward joining the European Union.
articles.personality_title_fr: Chypre soutient les progrès de la Macédoine du Nord vers l’adhésion à l’UE

Chypre reconnaît les efforts constants de la Macédoine du Nord pour améliorer ses lois et systèmes afin de correspondre à ceux de l’UE. Cela a été annoncé lors d’une réunion avec des responsables macédoniens le 26 janvier 2026.

**Impact** – Ce soutien est important car il montre que l’UE apprécie le travail de la Macédoine du Nord et souhaite que le pays devienne membre. Rejoindre l’UE signifie que la Macédoine du Nord pourra bénéficier d’une coopération plus étroite avec d’autres pays européens, d’institutions démocratiques renforcées et d’une plus grande stabilité dans la région. Cela montre aussi que l’UE se concentre sur l’équité, récompensant les pays selon leurs efforts.

**Prochaine étape** – La Macédoine du Nord continuera à travailler sur les réformes pour répondre aux exigences de l’UE. L’UE, dirigée par Chypre pour les six prochains mois, continuera à encourager un dialogue ouvert et un soutien. articles.personality_title_es: Chipre apoya los avances de Macedonia del Norte para unirse a la UE
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Macedonia del Norte está trabajando para unirse a la Unión Europea (UE), un grupo de 27 países en Europa. Este proceso requiere que el país haga muchos cambios para cumplir con las reglas y estándares de la UE. Chipre dirige actualmente la UE y está ayudando a guiar este proceso.

**Qué pasó** – Chipre, a través de su embajador Andreas Fotiou, dijo que continuará manteniendo un diálogo abierto y regular con los Balcanes Occidentales, incluida Macedonia del Norte. Chipre reconoce los esfuerzos continuos de Macedonia del Norte para mejorar sus leyes y sistemas para alinearse con los de la UE. Esto se comunicó durante una reunión con funcionarios de Macedonia del Norte el 26 de enero de 2026.

**Impacto** – Este apoyo es importante porque muestra que la UE valora el trabajo de Macedonia del Norte y quiere que el país sea miembro. Unirse a la UE significa que Macedonia del Norte puede beneficiarse de una cooperación más estrecha con otros países europeos, instituciones democráticas más fuertes y mayor estabilidad en la región. También muestra que la UE se enfoca en la justicia, recompensando a los países según sus esfuerzos.

**Próximo paso** – Macedonia del Norte continuará trabajando en reformas para cumplir con los requisitos de la UE. La UE, liderada por Chipre durante los próximos seis meses, seguirá fomentando el diálogo abierto y el apoyo. Ambas partes esperan avanzar en el proceso de ampliación, acercando a Macedonia del Norte a la membresía en la UE.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Chipre, al frente de la UE, elogia las reformas constantes de Macedonia del Norte y promete apoyar su camino hacia unirse a la Unión Europea.
